docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer, a bolt of hope shot through this city as the Bush administration edged toward granting legal residency to millions of illegal immigrants from Mexico and perhaps other countries. When the movement seemed to slow, President Vicente Fox of Mexico, in talks at the White House, sought to rebuild momentum for the proposal that would give individuals and families the prospect of moving out of the shadows and into mainstream working-class life.

headline.main: Legal Residency Hopes of Millions Dashed

docs.lead_paragraph: If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. ''This is just the initial wave of layoffs due to the attacks,'' Steven Wood, an economist, said. ''There's another wave behind it.''

headline.main: Unemployed Struggle to Make Do in Difficult Economic Times; Computer Expert Turns to Odd Jobs To Help Pay Bills

docs.snippet: If the United States was teetering on the edge of recession before Sept. 11, the terrorist attacks were a decisive shove over the edge. The number of workers filing for first-time state unemployment benefits has soared to a nine-year high. ''This is...

docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE Sept. 11, American progressives had reason to hope they might be emerging from the political wilderness. After years of bitter squabbles over identity politics and the merits of the Clinton administration, the left appeared to have reclaimed its anti-corporate heritage and was growing. For the first time since the 1930's, student activists and labor officials championed the same causes. At dozens of colleges, groups sought to curb sweatshop manufacturing in the developing world and to demand a living wage for employees at home. Organizers were predicting 100,000 protesters, including many union members, would be in Washington in late September during the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

headline.main: The Nation; After the Attacks, Which Side Is the Left On?

docs.abstract: Prospect of renascent, unified left, seemed increasingly likely before Sept 11, but has all but vanished since then; while labor leaders and liberal lawmakers endorse Bush administration's anti-terrorist campaign, radical foes of global capital on college campuses and in streets talk of peace and try to grasp why many in Islamic world seem to hate United States; photo (M)
docs.snippet: BEFORE Sept. 11, American progressives had reason to hope they might be emerging from the political wilderness. After years of bitter squabbles over identity politics and the merits of the Clinton administration, the left appeared to have reclaimed...

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS much I know about Sept. 11 and its uncertain aftermath: The last thing I expected in these days of community spirit was to be harassed on the street. Fashion was involved, I'm afraid. It happened like this: Walking up Third Avenue with my head in the clouds -- again -- I noticed two fellow citizens coming toward me. One of them was plainly dressed in dark clothing. The other man, decidedly more jaunty, was thoroughly hip-hop. He wore gigantic trousers and a tightly applied do-rag with a print of the American flag.
docs.abstract: William Norwich report describes being bumped and harrassed in New York after World Trade Center attack by man garbed in palazzo pants and American flag do-rag; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the United States activates thousands of military reservists in response to the terrorist attacks, businesses are deciding how to handle compensation and medical benefits for the affected employees and their families. For many employers, that is not a problem. About three-quarters already have policies in place, and many of them are fairly generous, according to a survey conducted by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a benefits consulting firm. The results were released last week.

headline.main: Survey Says Most Employers Have Policies for Reservists

docs.abstract: Watson Wyatt Worldwide survey finds that about three-quarters of employers have policies in place to handle compensation of activated military reservist employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a bright summer afternoon and the clock was approaching 4:15 p.m. David Sinish, a senior financial underwriter in downtown Hartford, was getting nervous. More than a decade of experience told him that he had five minutes to get to a commuter bus to Collinsville, but he was stuck on the telephone. ''I have to leave right now to catch that bus,'' Mr. Sinish said to the caller before hanging up.

headline.main: Working 9 to 5, Then Off to the Night Job

docs.abstract: Article on some of thousands of Connecticut residents who work second jobs at night; Labor Department figures show that Connecticut, at 5.9 percent, is slightly ahead of national average in number of people who hold multiple jobs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After the first plane hit the World Trade Center, the phone lines out of the center lit up as people frantically tried to reach loved ones. If someone had tapped into those lines, they would have heard a cacophony of voices in different languages, some consoling, others frightened. On one of those lines, Eliezer Jimenez Jr., 38, a cook at Windows on the World, had been telling his wife, Rosa, how to get to the Midtown dental office where she was to take their 8-year-old daughter, Genesis. Suddenly his voice became startled. ''Algo explotó en el edificio, yo te llamo,'' he said hurriedly from the kitchen on the 106th floor of the north tower. ''Something has exploded in the building, let me call you back.''

headline.main: Turning Off the Television, Raising the Children Alone

docs.abstract: Children's Aid Society, which receives assistance from New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund, assists Rosa Jimenez, whose husband is missing after collapse of World Trade Center, in buying necessities for her children; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN stock prices slide, ordinary investors suffer varying degrees of distress and may look for someone to blame for their losses. But they typically have the option of moving into less risky securities or even to the sidelines. Professionals generally enjoy less flexibility, especially those who manage publicly traded mutual funds. Consider Robert E. Turner and his colleagues at Turner Investment Partners, a growth-oriented firm that manages $7.6 billion, roughly half in funds and half in private accounts for pension funds and other institutions. The firm lives by some of the more rigid restrictions in the industry.

headline.main: A Fund Firm Adjusts, Within Boundaries

docs.abstract: Turner Investment Partners, Berwyn, Pa, growth-oriented firm that manages $7.6 billion in mutual funds and private accounts, adjusts its portfolios within relatively rigid restrictions as it attempts to accommodate to post-terrorist-attack market climate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush called on Congress today to use nearly all the money remaining for the proposed economic recovery plan for at least $60 billion of tax cuts. Democrats immediately replied that increased government spending to create jobs and help the unemployed should be a big part of the package. ''Congress doesn't need to spend any more money,'' Mr. Bush said. ''What they need to do is cut taxes.''

headline.main: Bush Wants More Tax Cuts In Effort to Help Economy

docs.lead_paragraph: Mike Mansfield, who served as Senate majority leader longer than anyone else and was instrumental in the 1960's and 1970's in the enactment of legislation on civil rights, social policy and foreign affairs that changed the course of the country, died today at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 98. Mr. Mansfield lived in Washington and went to his office at Goldman Sachs Group almost every weekday until last week, when he went into the hospital, said his assistant, Barbara Hickey.

headline.main: Mike Mansfield, Longtime Leader Of Senate Democrats, Dies at 98

docs.abstract: Mike Mansfield, who served as Senate majority leader for record 16 years and was major figure in legislation of 1960's and 1970's, dies at age 98; Montana Democrat, modest and self-effacing, served in House for ten years and in Senate for 24, then became US ambassador to Japan for ten years and was revered there; his long influence in public policy reviewed; photos; son of Irish immigrants was born in New York and sent to Montana at age 3 after mother died; he joined Navy at age 14 during World War II, serving later in Army and Marine Corps as well (L)
